items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  8.05
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, Randy Phelps, Director of Information Technology, Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager, and Jeanine Lovejoy, The Consulting Group
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Receive Report on Districtwide Security Cameras, and Approve Professional Service Contract for Design Services 
		 
		 
On August 22, 2013 (Item 14.01), the Board received a report on the status of security cameras at our school sites.  Cameras installed in the past employ older technology, some of which is obsolete, and are ad hoc systems that do not or cannot integrate into an enterprise level solution.
		 
On September 19, 2013 (Item 15.02), The Consulting Group was awarded a contract to study and report on the current condition of the District’s security cameras, and to provide recommendations toward a modern, integrated solution.  They conducted physical assessments of existing cameras, cabling, storage devices and technology platforms.  They also conducted a risk assessment by interviewing school site and district staff to ascertain areas of historic or perceived risk, as well as surveying each campus’ physical condition.  They have provided a comprehensive report that includes recommendations on how to migrate from existing disintegrated, legacy systems to an integrated, enterprise level solution that employs current technology (Executive Summary attached). The Consulting Group will present their findings and recommendations (presentation attached).
		 
The estimated cost to implement a districtwide enterprise level, IP-based camera solution that provides coverage to all areas of each site as identified in the report is five million dollars ($5M).  Current bond Measure E funding available for this project is $1M.  Supplemental funding as follows could be allocated to support this project:  $1M of Capital Facilities Fund 25; $2M of bond Measure I infrastructure funding; $1M of School Facility Fund 35.  Administration recommends this comprehensive provision of security cameras, in order to provide coverage where needed to provide deterrence against unwanted behavior, detection and assessment of unwanted events, rapid assessment in a safety emergency, the ability to gather evidence and subjects of interest pursuant to immediate action or in support of a forensic investigation, at the lowest life cycle cost.  
		 
A possible scaled back option (Alternate Option 1) would be installation of an enterprise level, IP-based camera solution at only the sites that experience the highest incidents (e.g., Andrew Hill, Mount Pleasant, Silver Creek, Yerba Buena), as well as the District Office.  The estimated cost for this option would be $1.6M.  
		 
Another scaled back option (Alternate Option 2) would be Option 1 plus replacement of broken cameras at other campuses.  The estimated cost for this option would be $2.8M.  
		 
Administration recommends authorizing The Consulting Group to develop plans and specifications that would allow the District to bid and award an installation contract for the comprehensive districtwide, enterprise level, IP-based camera solution.  The preconstruction period (design, bid, approval and award) is estimated to take seven months.  Construction/installation team(s) would move from site to site within an estimated six to nine month period.  As each site is completed, their cameras would be fully operational.  With this schedule, an integrated, enterprise level security camera system that employs current technology would be in place by Spring 2015.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$260,000.00 
           
;
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve a professional service contract for The Consulting Group, in the amount of $260,000, to develop plans and specifications for a Districtwide Security Camera System, and to delegate authority to the Superintendent or designee to amend the contract and purchase order on an as needed basis, including funding.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
					 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Charter Petition for B. Roberto 
Cruz Leadership Academy High School
	 
  
I.  Brief Summary
 
The petitioner in this matter is the NHU Foundation, which submitted a petition (“Petition”) to establish the B. Roberto Cruz Academy Charter School (“BRC”) dated April 29, 2013, and was received by the Board of Trustees on May 9, 2013.  A public hearing was held at the June 11, 2013, Regular Board Meeting pursuant to Education Code section 47605(a).  At the August 22, 2013, Regular Board Meeting the Governing Board approved the administration’s recommendation of a conditional approval for a term of 2 years to end on June 30, 2015.
   
Condition #1:  Petitioner must submit to the District documentation from UC Doorways that LCPA 1 has the minimum 15 courses required to certify students UC a-g eligible by April 15, 2014. 
 
LCPA 1 has submitted to UC Doorways the remaining courses needed to have the minimum 15 courses required to certify students are UC A-G eligible.  LCPA 1 is waiting for the courses to be reviewed by UC Doorways and subsequently notified if they are approved.  Condition is pending notification from UC Doorways and if one or more of the courses submitted is not approved, then LCPA 1 will have to continue the process until all 15 courses have been approved.  
 
Condition #2:  Submit proof of intended enrollment by June 15, 2014, for LCPA 1, LCPA II, and BRC.  Such proof shall include signed statements from parents identifying their student by name, age, and grade level, and that they have enrolled or intended to enroll such student in LCPA 1, LCPA II or BRC. 
 
This condition has not been met; however, this is addressed in the MOU approved by the Governing Board at the December 12, 2013, Regular Board Meeting.  An enrollment timeline has been established by the MOU and petitioners have to submit proof of enrollment by June 15, 2014, in order to open for the 2014-2015 school year.
 
Condition #3:  Submit proof that the NHU Foundation has acquired an appropriate facility to house the BRC school with appropriate proof of insurance by July 1, 2014.
 
Currently, the petitioners have not submitted proof that they have obtained a facility; however, this is addressed in the MOU approved by the Governing Board at the December 12, 2013, Regular Board Meeting as part of the opening requirements and is due by July 1, 2014.  
 
Condition #4:  Successfully negotiate an acceptable MOU agreement with the District by November 30, 2013.
 
The MOU was approved by the Governing Board at the December 12, 2013, Regular Board Meeting.
 
The MOU address the areas of: 
•         Establishment of the school and location 
•         The Authorizer – school relationship 
•         School opening criteria and timelines 
•         Budget and accounting timelines 
•         Authorizer authority parameters 
•         Special Education services 
•         Student conduct and discipline 
•         Evaluation 
•         Term of the charter 
•         Governance 
•         Student records and assessments 
•         Dispute resolution 
•         School closure procedures 
•         Insurance 
•         Human Resources 
•         Service contracts 
•         Any special conditions 
 
 
Condition #5:  Correct deficiencies in the charter petitions noted in the evaluation matrix submitted to the Board during these authorization proceedings by no later than January 30, 2014.
 
NHU Foundation submitted a revised charter petition on December 18, 2013.  Staff is in the process of reviewing the petition to ensure that the deficiencies outlined in the evaluation matrix have been corrected and will continue to work with the petitioners until all deficiencies are corrected.
 
Administration feels that, although not all the conditions have been fully met, the NHU Foundation has made a good effort in meeting conditions #1, #4, and #5 and conditions #2 and #3 are guaranteed as a condition of opening in the MOU. The NHU Foundation has applied and was granted a charter school grant through the California Department of Education and, in order to receive these funds, they must submit a District authorized petition clear of any conditions.
 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the District administration to sign off on the conditions of approval for the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter petition once the petitioners have satisfactorily met condition #5.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the district administration to sign off on the conditions of approval for the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter petition once the petitioners have satisfactorily met condition #5.

PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
					 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Charter Petition for Latino College
Preparatory Academy II (LCPA II)
	 
I.  Brief Summary
 
The petitioner in this matter is the NHU Foundation, which submitted a petition (“Petition”) to establish the Latino College Preparatory Academy II (LCPA II) dated April 29, 2013, and was received by the Board of Trustees on May 9, 2013.  A public hearing was held at the June 11, 2013, Regular Board Meeting pursuant to Education Code section 47605(a).  At the August 22, 2013, Regular Board Meeting the Governing Board approved the administration’s recommendation of a conditional approval for a term of 2 years to end on June 30, 2015.
   
Condition #1:  Petitioner must submit to the District documentation from UC Doorways that LCPA 1 has the minimum 15 courses required to certify students UC a-g eligible by April 15, 2014. 
 
LCPA 1 has submitted to UC Doorways the remaining courses needed to have the minimum 15 courses required to certify students are UC A-G eligible.  LCPA 1 is waiting for the courses to be reviewed by UC Doorways and subsequently notified if they are approved.  Condition is pending notification from UC Doorways and if one or more of the courses submitted is not approved, then LCPA 1 will have to continue the process until all 15 courses have been approved.
 
Condition #2:  Submit proof of intended enrollment by June 15, 2014, for LCPA 1, LCPA II, and BRC.  Such proof shall include signed statements from parents identifying their student by name, age, and grade level, and that they have enrolled or intended to enroll such student in LCPA 1, LCPA II or BRC. 
 
This condition has not been met; however, this is addressed in the MOU approved by the Governing Board at the December 12, 2013, Regular Board Meeting.  An enrollment timeline has been established by the MOU and petitioners have to submit proof of enrollment by June 15, 2014, in order to open for the 2014-2015 school year.
 
Condition #3:  Submit proof that the NHU Foundation has acquired an appropriate facility to house the LCPA II school with appropriate proof of insurance by July 1, 2014.
 
Currently, the petitioners have not submitted proof that they have obtained a facility; however, this is addressed in the MOU approved by the Governing Board at the December 12, 2013, Regular Board Meeting as part of the opening requirements and is due by July 1, 2014.  
 
Condition #4:  Successfully negotiate an acceptable MOU agreement with the District by November 30, 2013.
 
The MOU was approved by the Governing Board at the December 12, 2013 Regular Board Meeting.
 
The MOU address the areas of: 
•          Establishment of the school and location 
•          The Authorizer – school relationship 
•          School opening criteria and timelines 
•          Budget and accounting timelines 
•          Authorizer authority parameters 
•          Special Education services 
•          Student conduct and discipline 
•          Evaluation 
•          Term of the charter 
•          Governance 
•          Student records and assessments 
•          Dispute resolution 
•          School closure procedures 
•          Insurance 
•          Human Resources 
•          Service contracts 
•          Any special conditions 
 
 
Condition #5:  Correct deficiencies in the charter petitions noted in the evaluation matrix submitted to the Board during these authorization proceedings by no later than January 30, 2014.
 
NHU Foundation submitted a revised charter petition on December 18, 2013.  Staff is in the process of reviewing the petition to ensure that the deficiencies outlined in the evaluation matrix have been corrected and will continue to work with the petitioners until all deficiencies are corrected.
 
Additional Request by the charter petitioners:
 
The NHU Foundation is requesting that the Latino College Preparatory II Charter school be renamed Luis Valdez Leadership Academy.  The Governing Board of LCPA II has approved the name change and is requesting that the ESUHSD Board of Trustees also approve the name change.  The revised petition submitted in response to Condition #5 above reflects the name change.
 
Administration feels that although not all the conditions have been fully met, the NHU Foundation has made a good effort in meeting conditions #1, #4, and #5 and conditions #2 and #3 are guaranteed as a condition of opening in the MOU. The NHU Foundation has applied and was granted a charter school grant through the California Department of Education and, in order to receive these funds, they must submit a District authorized petition clear of any conditions.
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the name change from Latino College Preparatory Academy II (LCPA II) to Luis Valdez Leadership Academy and to authorize the District administration to sign off on the conditions of approval for the LCPA II (aka Luis Valdez Leadership Academy) charter petition once the petitioners have satisfactorily met condition #5.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary Education
					 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Receive Fourth Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering October 1, 2013, through December 31, 2013, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case, California public schools are required to provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12, inclusive, shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from October 1, 2013, through December 31, 2013.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Fourth Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering October 1, 2013, through December 31, 2013, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, Julio Lucas, District Architect, Kenneth Kerch, Bond Program Manager, SGI, Bettina Lopez, Andrew Hill High School Principal, George Sanchez, Foothill High School Principal, Grettel Castro-Stanley, Independence High School Principal, Glenn Vander Zee, James Lick High School Principal, Teresa Marquez, Mt. Pleasant High School Principal, and Vito Chiala, W.C. Overfelt High School Principal
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve 2013 Capital Construction Project Lists for Andrew Hill High School, Foothill High School, Independence High School, James Lick High School, Mt. Pleasant High School, and W.C. Overfelt High School
	 
On June 27, 2013 (Item 15.05) the Board of Trustees approved an Equity Distribution of Measure I funds to District sites (Attachment A).  
	 
An inclusive and collaborative planning process transpired since that time, to identify needs and develop recommendations for how each site would use Measure I allocations. The process built upon the planning work completed in 2008/2009 for Measure E, and mimicked the planning, recommendation and approval process put in place for Measure E, as follows:
	 
Historical Analysis
                 A review of past planning initiatives were conducted to ascertain projects that were identified, prioritized, and either implemented or deferred; those planning initiatives include the 2004 Facilities Master Plan, facilities condition and infrastructure studies, as well as previous Bond Measures A, G and E plans and outcomes.
School Site Council Project Lists
                 Historical analysis reports were reviewed by Facilities Planning and Bond Program Management staff, and Site administration.  School Site Councils collaborated with Site administration and Bond Planning staff to update their project lists. Project lists were developed and prioritized based on the District’s Strategic Plan, as well as the criteria upon which Measure I funding was allocated (API/SED/EL, SPED, Permanent Modernized Space Capacity)
Superintendent’s Council 
                 Proposed Project Lists were presented to Superintendent’s Council for review and recommendation.  In some instances when further discussion was warranted, a second round of review was conducted that included the school Principal.  As needed, School Site Councils were re-engaged for further discussion and approval.   
	 
The 2013 Project Lists for Andrew Hill High School, Foothill High School, Independence High School, James Lick High School, Mt. Pleasant High School, and W.C. Overfelt High School are presented herewith for Board discussion and approval.  The Project Lists for Evergreen Valley High School, Oak Grove High School, Piedmont Hills High School, Silver Creek High School, Santa Teresa High School, Yerba Buena High School, Phoenix High School, and Independence Adult Center will be presented at the February Board meeting. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:  
Not Applicable                                     
	 
                                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the 2013 Project Lists for Andrew Hill High School, Foothill High School, Independence High School, James Lick High School, Mt. Pleasant High School, W.C. Overfelt High School.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.06
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects, Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Proposed Program Management Services Agreement between East Side Union High School District and The Seville Group
					 
					 
	 
The Governing Board previously awarded contracts to The Seville Group, a California corporation (“SGI”), to provide Bond Program services in connection with the District’s Measure G and Measure E bond programs.  The District’s program management agreement with SGI for Measure G was first entered into in April 2003, and has been extended by the Board through amendment to currently expire on February 28, 2014.   The District’s program management agreement with SGI for Measure E was first entered into in September 2008, and has been extended by the Board through amendment to currently expire on February 28, 2014. 
	 
The Board has not previously awarded any comprehensive contract for program management services for the District’s Measure I Bond Program.
	 
At the Regular Board Meeting of February 14, 2013, the Board unanimously approved the solicitation of the RFQ/P process for program management services for District’s Measure G, Measure E and Measure I Bond Programs.  
	 
The RFQ/P for program management services was issued by Administration on March 25, 2013.  A total of 6 firms responded and were evaluated by Administration.
	 
At the Regular Board Meeting on June 27, 2013, the Administration (in connection with its preparing a recommendation to the Board) proposed and the Board approved, to obtain a performance audit/facilities program management review of the District’s Measure G and Measure E Bond Programs.  The approved scope of the audit was to include the performance of the management of the Measure G and Measure E Bond Programs by SGI.  Upon completion of the performance audit and review and analysis of the results by staff, the Administration would present its recommendation to the Board regarding on-going program management services for the District’s Bond Programs.
	 
Total School Solutions (“TSS”) was selected by the District to conduct the performance audit.
	 
The performance audit was completed by TSS, dated September 13, 2013, and was delivered to the District.  The TSS performance audit report was “sunshined” and presented by TSS to the Board in open session at the Regular Meeting of September 19, 2013.
	 
Administration has analyzed and considered the audit report results.  In connection with that review and analysis, Administration proposed, and the Board approved, the reorganization of the District’s capital programs to address the staffing and financial management weaknesses cited in the TSS performance audit report.  The reorganization was approved at the Regular Board Meeting of October 17, 2013.  The approved reorganization includes the transition “in-house” to District staff of Bond Program management tasks currently performed under contract by SGI, including the creation of a new Capital Accounting Department to provide Bond Program financial management and to expand Capital Purchasing to provide vendor relations, qualifications and evaluations, and comprehensive capital purchasing duties in addition to the contract administration and labor compliance work also currently being performed by SGI.  This reorganization will provide clarity of roles and responsibilities, which have historically resulted in program inefficiencies; the strategic goal of the reorganization is to increase program quality while also realizing $1.3 million annual cost savings in comparison to what the District currently pays to have these services performed by SGI.  Implementation of the reorganization is underway.
	 
In light of the Board-approved reorganization, the scope of the RFQ/P for program management services originally issued by the District in March 25, 2013, is no longer relevant or fully accurate.  Instead, the scope of work has been substantially narrowed, with a considerable amount of the financial management and accounting now to be performed and administered directly by District staff.  
	 
After review and consideration of the TSS performance audit report and the findings and recommendations, SGI’s experience and past performance, the recent RFQ/P process and the on-going capital program reorganization, Administration considers that SGI is best-positioned to continue to serve in the role and provide the services of Program Manager for Measure G, Measure E and Measure I, as now modified and narrowed by the capital program reorganization.  On that basis, Administration has been in on-going negotiations with SGI for a “Program Management Services Agreement for Measures “G”, “E” and “I” General Obligation School Facilities Bond Program”, which Administration now presents and recommends for Board approval (the “Proposed Agreement”).
	 
The proposed Agreement has the following key material terms:
	 
Effective Date:  February 1, 2014.
	 
Term of Agreement:  Initial period of February 1, 2014 – December 1, 2017; two (2) additional one-year renewal options at District’s discretion.  (Art. XVI(3).)
	 
Program Management Fee:  Total fee not to exceed $6,612,505.00 (3.7%), allocated between Measure G, Measure E, and Measure I and based on a total combined Bond Program budget of $178,744,481, as follows:
	 
Bond Program
Budget Per Bond Program
Maximum Fee per Bond Program
Measure G
$43,444,931.00
$1,607,176.00
Measure E
$27,422,019.00
$1,014,209.00
Measure I
$107,877,531.00
$3,991,120.00
Totals
$178,744,481.00
$6,612,505.00
	 
	 
(Proposed Agreement, Art. XV and Art. XVI)
	 
Termination Rights:  The proposed Agreement, as with previous agreements, contains a termination provision including rights of termination for cause and termination for convenience upon 60-days written notice by District.
	 
The proposed Agreement addresses the issues, recommendation and deficiencies raised in the 2010 FCMAT Extraordinary Audit and in the September 2013, TSS Performance Audit.  Approval of the proposed Agreement will result in the termination of the existing Measure G and Measure E program management agreements effective February 1, 2014.  (Art. I(1))
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:                           
Not to exceed $6,612,505.00 for the services set forth in the proposed Agreement.
	 
FUNDING SOURCES:
Measure G, Measure E and Measure I
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Program Management Services Agreement for Measures “G”, “E” and “I” General Obligation School Facilities Bond Program as presented.

Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Notice of Completion for Overfelt Adult Center Project Increments 1 Project, E-042-001(Cal-Pacific Construction Inc.)
				 
				 
				 
	 
Pursuant to the contract awarded by the Board of Trustees on April 19, 2012, Cal-Pacific Construction Inc., has furnished all material and finished all labor for the completion of work related to the Overfelt Adult Center Increments 1 Project.
	 
With the approval of the Board of Trustees, the attached Notice of Completion will be filed with the Santa Clara County Recorder’s Office as required by law.

It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Notice of Completion for Overfelt Adult Center Increments 1 Project, E-042-001 (Cal-Pacific Construction Inc.).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  20.09
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approval of Measure I Distribution for ACE Charter School
					 
					 
	 
	 
Under Proposition 39, ACE Charter School is eligible for the District’s Bond Measure I proceeds.  Bond funds may only be used to construct classrooms and educational facilities for District students within the District boundaries and/or to provide appropriate equipment.  On June 27, 2013, the Board of Trustees approved a Measure I Equity Distribution List that allocated funds to ACE Charter School in the amount of $10,159 (Board item 15.05). 
	 
ACE serves 101 students.  Of those students, 82 reside within East Side Union High School District boundaries.  ACE has identified a need to assist with the construction of their new campus which is currently being planned to be located on property of the Alum Rock School District.  ACE would like to use its Measure I allocation to offset architectural costs for this endeavor.

FISCAL IMPACT: 
$10,159.00                                                   
           
                                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure I
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve distribution of Measure I bond funds for assistance with architectural costs for the construction of a new campus for ACE Charter School within the Alum Rock School District boundaries, conditioned upon ACE securing and providing proof of a lease to use, occupy and construct its high school campus on Alum Rock School District property.
